EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This document comprises the Five Year Update for the Federal Risk Management Plan (Federal RMP Plan) and the California Accidental Release Prevention Program Risk Management Plan (CalARP RMP) for Lake Operations located at 13200 Main Street in Trona, California 93562 (hereinafter referred to as the facility or the subject facility).  Lake Operations is owned and operated by Searles Valley Minerals which is a sub-division of IMC Global.  Searles Valley Minerals? initial submittal for this facility was made to USEPA and to the San Bernardino County Fire Department on June 21, 1999.

The purpose of this document is to comply with the risk management planning and update requirements as set forth in the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Part 68 (also known as the Federal Risk Management Plan Regulations) and the California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Article 3, Section 2745.3 (also known as the California Accidental Release Prevention Program Risk Management Plan ? CalARP RMP Regulations).  The scope of the Federal RMP and CalARP RMP includes all operations conducted at the subject facility that involve the storage and handling of chlorine (i.e., chlorine is the only regulated substance handled at the Lake Operations Chlorine Storage Facility).

Searles Valley Minerals is strongly committed to the health and safety of its employees, the public and the environment.  This commitment is demonstrated by the comprehensive accidental release prevention program implemented at Lake Operations covering aspects of operations such as design, installation, operations and maintenance, training, emergency response and other areas.  It is the Policy of Searles Valley Minerals to implement appropriate controls to prevent potential releases of regulated substances.  This is achieved through strong leadership, teamwork, effective communications, and by striving towards continuous improvement in all business areas.

This commitment is con

sistent with the company?s environmental, health and safety policy that provides that:
?    ALL facilities will be designed, operated, and managed to protect the health and safety of employees and the public;
?    ALL employees will be educated on the applicable environmental, health and safety standards and procedures;
?    Sufficient human and financial resources will be allocated to sustain these goals; and
?    Audits will be conducted regularly to verify compliance with this Policy.

These Corporate Policies also emphasize the importance of complying with OSHA?s Process Safety Management Standard (as well as the RMP and CalARP regulations), so that ALL employees and the surrounding community will be adequately protected from potential fire, explosion, and/or toxic release hazards associated with catastrophic releases.

Searles Valley Minerals is also proud to be an active participant in the Chemical Manufacturers Association ? Responsible Care Program.  As such, Searles Valley Minerals pledges to manage its business according to the principles of the Responsible Care Program.  As a member of CMA, Searles Valley Minerals is also committed to supporting a continuous effort to improve the industry?s responsible management of chemicals.  

ES 1.0    DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The primary activity conducted at the Lake Operations Chlorine Storage Facility is the storage of chlorine (which is moved as received, in one ton containers, from the Lake Operations Chlorine Storage Facility to the Trona Facility as needed).  Since activities at Lake Operations support the Trona Facility, activities at Lake Operations can be categorized as the manufacture of inorganic chemicals (NAICS Code 325188 ? All Other Basic Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing).  

Facility Location
Searles Valley Minerals ? Lake Operations is located in California?s Mojave Desert, in the Searles Valley, west of Searles Lake at 13200 Main Street in Trona, California 93562.  The La

ke Operations Chlorine Storage Facility (where chlorine is stored is located approximately two-miles southeast of Trona ? along Oscar Johnson Road on the Searles Lake Bed).  

Facility Description
As stated previously, Lake Operations is part of Searles Valley Minerals, which is a subdivision of IMC Global.  The company's Searles Valley facilities, tap into one of the richest sources of diversified minerals and chemicals on earth ? the location contains 98 of the world's 110 known chemical elements.  Searles Valley Minerals extracts, chemically processes and ships minerals and inorganic chemical compounds to customers all over the world.  The company currently produces soda ash, sodium borates, boric acid and natural sulfate.  

A unique liquid-liquid extraction (LLX) process for manufacturing boric acid has been operated at the Facility since 1962.  An organic extractant was developed and patented for use in this process.  The boric acid process is based on the ability of the organic extractant to form a compound with certain boron compounds found in the Searles Lake brines to form a compound that has very specific properties.  

Boric acid production consists of 2 processes: liquid-liquid extraction (LLX) and evaporation-crystallization.  The liquid-liquid extraction process consists of 2 sections:
1.    A loading section where boron, sodium and potassium are extracted from the lake brine, and combined into the organic extractant used in the LLX Plant. 
2.    A stripping section where the boron, sodium and potassium are stripped from the organic extractant by contact with a dilute acidic aqueous solution to form an aqueous solution of boric acid and sodium and potassium sulfates (called the strip solution), and to regenerate the extractant for re-contact with Lake Brine.

In the evaporation-crystallization section the dilute aqueous strip solution is evaporated and the boric acid is separated from the mixed sulfates by fractional crystallization.

Description of Regulat

ed Substance Use
The extractant is produced at the Searles Valley Minerals Trona Facility by mixing a manufactured product (called P20) with kerosene in predetermined volumes according to specific procedures.  P20 is produced in the P20 Plant (at the Trona Facility) and it can be described as a 50% weight solution of specific phenolic compounds in a kerosene base.  The purpose of P20 is to provide the raw material for making the extractant utilized at the LLX plant.

Chlorine (a regulated substances) alongwith other raw materials is used in the manufacture of the P20 Product (as such a separate RMP has been submitted for the Searles Valley Minerals Trona Facility).  One ton containers of chlorine are stored at the Lake Operations Chlorine Storage Facility for eventual transport to- and use at- the Trona Facility.  Up to a maximum of ten one-ton containers of chlorine may be stored at the Lake Operations Chlorine Facility at any one time.  These containers are stored on a double row set of rails (on a concrete slab) at ground level and protected from rolling by chocks.  A roof over the slab provides the containers protection from solar heating.  The Chlorine Storage Facility is located in an isolated and unpopulated location along Oscar Johnson Road on Searles Valley Minerals?s Lake Property.  The only activity conducted at the Chlorine Storage Facility is the storage and handling of one-ton chlorine containers (as received from the chlorine vendor).  No connections are made to the chlorine containers are made at this location.

Searles Valley Minerals personnel pick up containers with a crane and a special handling device (certified spanner bar), place them on a licensed transport trailer equipped with a cradle and mechanical restraints and deliver the containers to the Trona Facility (at the P20 Plant).  The site has been used for the storage of one-ton chlorine containers for over 20-years.

Site Security
A chain link fence prohibits unauthorized entry or access t

o the Lake Operations Chlorine Storage Facility.  Additionally, the area is protected via 24-hour security.  These site security provisions are intended to prevent unauthorized access to specific areas including those areas where chlorine is stored and handled, thus adding a level of safety for the storage of chlorine at the site.

ES 2.0    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE SCENARIOS

The Federal RMP regulations and the CalARP RMP regulations require that at least two types of release scenarios be evaluated for their potential to impact off-site populations:

?    the worst case release; and
?    an alternative release (an accident scenario that is more credible than the worst-case release scenario).

A number of hypothetical accidental release scenarios were postulated and evaluated for the Five Year Federal RMP/CalARP RMP Update.  These scenarios were categorized into worst-case release scenarios and alternative release scenarios.  Each of these categories of hypothetical accidental release scenarios is discussed below.

CHLORINE

Worst-Case Release Scenario
In this scenario, one of the ten one-ton containers of chlorine stored at the Chlorine Storage Facility experiences a catastrophic failure due to an unknown event.  This scenario could be initiated by an external event (i.e., an airplane, missile or meteorite impacting the Chlorine Storage Facility where the one ton containers are located/stored).  It is highly improbable that this scenario would be initiated by a seismic event.  However, the possibility of this scenario being initiated by a seismic event cannot be completely discarded.  This scenario is considered to be extremely unlikely.  In the extremely unlikely case that this scenario occurs, up to 2,000-pounds of chlorine could be released (in the worst-case).  The release of chlorine would occur outdoors.  Thus, it was assumed that the chlorine released during the catastrophic accident form a cloud of chlorine vapor which is free to migrate off-site.  Utilizing the BREEZE DE

GADIS PLUS MODEL, the estimated vulnerable zone for this hypothetical accidental release scenario is approximately 1.7-miles.

Alternative Release Scenarios
Alternative release scenarios which are considered to be more likely to occur are those which may result in the release of anywhere from less than one-pound to up to 2000-pounds of chlorine.  These scenarios include situations such as delivery of a leaking one-ton container of chlorine to the Chlorine Storage Facility, a pinhole leak in one of the chlorine containers that develops some time after delivery and acceptance of the container or a variety of transportation accidents involving a chlorine container during either delivery to the Chlorine Storage Facility or delivery from the Chlorine Storage Facility to the Trona Facility.  In order to be conservative in the estimation of the vulnerable zone, it was assumed that 2000-pounds of chlorine gas were released during an event in which the valve on one of the containers is sheared off due to some unknown external event.  The resulting cloud of chlorine vapor was assumed to freely migrate off-site.  Utilizing the BREEZE DEGADIS PLUS MODEL, the estimated vulnerable zone for this hypothetical accidental release scenario is approximately 1.3-miles.

ES 3.0    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

During the five years preceding the submittal of the Five Year Federal RMP/CalARP RMP Update (i.e., from June 21, 1999 through June 21, 2004), the Facility has NOT had any releases of chlorine that have resulted in:
?    Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or
?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.

ES 4.0    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Accidental Release Prevention Program at Lake Operations consists of a series of programs, procedures and policies designed to minimize the risk of accidental releases involving chlorine.  These programs include desig

n and operating controls such as compliance with specified codes, the Company?s health and safety program, numerous standard operating procedures, the equipment inspection and maintenance program (including a mechanical integrity and preventive maintenance program), the management of change program, pre-start-up review, fire protection and hot work permit programs, management of- and safety of- contractors, accident/incident investigation procedures, emergency response plans, the Federal RMP/CalARP RMP/OSHA PSM Program compliance auditing program, the Federal RMP/CalARP RMP/OSHA PSM Program record keeping program and a variety of personnel training programs.  Details of each of these components of the Lake Operations Accidental Release Prevention Program are provided in the document entitled Federal Risk Management Plan (Federal RMP), California Accidental Release Prevention Program Risk Management Plan (CalARP RMP), OSHA Process Safety Management (OSHA PSM) Program, Volume I - Prevention Program.  

There are a number of detection and monitoring devices and alarms designed to ensure the continued safe operation of the Lake Operations Chlorine Storage Facility.  

ES 5.0    EMERGENCY RESPONSE

Searles Valley Minerals recognizes that emergency preparedness, emergency planning and emergency response are an integral component of risk management.   As such, two extensive and detailed emergency response plans have been developed and implemented at for the Lake Operations Chlorine Storage Facility.  These Plans include ALL aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuation and notification of LERC/LEPD and the Public.

ALL emergency response equipment is frequently tested, inspected and serviced to ensure proper functioning.  The emergency evacuation sirens are tested every Friday at noon.  In addition, the emergency response plans are reviewed periodically and updated (as needed) to reflect pertinent changes in processes, operations

and/or personnel that may require a modified emergency response.  Emergency response drills and exercises are conducted periodically to ensure rapid response and effectiveness of the emergency response team.  ALL employees and contractors are trained in the requirements of these emergency response plans.

In the unlikely event that a release does occur, Searles Valley Minerals environmental, health and safety (EHS) staff and HazWOper trained emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release.  Searles Valley Minerals coordinates its emergency response actions and efforts with several State and County Agencies including the San Bernardino County (Volunteer) Fire Agency.  These activities provide additional emergency response expertise to both the community and Searles Valley Minerals facilities.

ES 6.0    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

A detailed hazard and operability study update (i.e., process hazards analysis update) was performed on ALL operations involving chlorine in order to enhance the safety of the Lake Operations Chlorine Storage Facility and to evaluate the potential for accidental releases.  As a result of the process hazards analysis update performed a number of recommendations were made.  Searles Valley Minerals has already completed/implemented a number of the recommended actions.  

ES 7.0    FOR MORE INFORMATION

Searles Valley Minerals recognizes that some persons may be interested in obtaining more detailed information regarding the Five Year Federal RMP and CalARP RMP Update and various Prevention Program components not discussed herein.  Interested parties that have additional questions regarding the Lake Operations Chlorine Storage Facility Risk Management Plan and or the Chlorine Prevention Program, are directed to contact:
